column5: VariableDescription

column2: Will be included in every table

column5: A unique subject id assigned by the PCDC. Any given individual person will have only one PCDC_SUBJECT_ID regardless of the number of studies in which they appear. If an individual person is on studies from more than one contributor, they may have more than one HONEST_BROKER_SUBJECT_IDs assigned to them by the contributors, but will be resulted to a single PCDC_SUBJECT_ID by PCDC staff.

column2: One row per subject per study

column5: Subject identifier assigned by the honest broker.
An identifier assigned to a data contributor.
A sequence of characters used to identify, name, or characterize the study.
Censor Status

column7: Subject is censored (i.e. has had no events(s)
Subject has had one or more events

column5: A specific treatment plan within a clinical trial that describes the activities a subject will be involved in as he or she progresses through the study.

column2: One row per subject per disease phase

column5: The stage or period of an individual's disease.

column8: The first diagnosis of the individual's condition.
The return of a disease after a period of remission.
The worsening of a disease over time.

column5: The number of the disease phase.
Age in days when the diagnosis was made for the disease phase.
Year when the diagnosis was made for the disease phase.

column2: One row per subject per course

column5: The type of protocol treatment course administered.

column8: A chemotherapy treatment administered prior to the definitive chemotherapy treatment.
The first choice of treatment for a particular type of cancer.
A second round of intense chemotherapy as part of consolidation therapy.
Treatment that is given after initial therapy to kill any remaining cancer cells.
Continuation of treatment for an extended period of time to prevent relapse.

column5: The number assigned to a course of therapeutic agent administration, indicating where a particular course of treatment falls within a sequence of treatments.
Age of subject (in days) at the start of the course.
Age of subject (in days) at the end of the course.
The assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female; the physical difference between male and female; the distinguishing peculiarity of male or female.

column8: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces ova. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, or cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

column5: An arbitrary classification of a taxonomic group that is a division of a species. It usually arises as a consequence of geographical isolation within a species and is characterized by shared heredity, physical attributes and behavior, and in the case of humans, by common history, nationality, or geographic distribution.

column8: A person having origins in any of the original peoples of North and South America (including Central America) and who maintains tribal affiliation or community attachment. (OMB)

A person having origins in any of the original peoples of the Far East, Southeast Asia, or the Indian subcontinent, including for example, Cambodia, China, India, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Pakistan, the Philippine Islands, Thailand, and Vietnam. (OMB)
A person having origins in any of the Black racial groups of Africa. Terms such as "Haitian" or "Negro" can be used in addition to "Black or African American". (OMB)
Having ancestors of several or various races.

column7: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander
column8: A person having origins in any of the original peoples of Hawaii, Guam, Samoa, or other Pacific Islands. (OMB)
A person having origins in any of the original peoples of Europe, the Middle East, or North Africa. (OMB)
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

column5: A social group characterized by a distinctive social and cultural tradition that is maintained from generation to generation. Members share a common history and origin and a sense of identification with the group. They have similar and distinctive features in their lifestyle habits and shared experiences. They often have a common genetic heritage which may be reflected in their experience of health and disease.

column8: A person of Cuban, Mexican, Puerto Rican, South or Central American, or other Spanish culture or origin, regardless of race. The term, "Spanish origin," can be used in addition to "Hispanic or Latino." (OMB)
A person not of Cuban, Mexican, Puerto Rican, South or Central American, or other Spanish culture or origin, regardless of race.
Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

The individual's last known survival status.

column2: One row per subject per histologic assessment

column5: Age of subject (in days) at histology assessment.

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs. In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

column10: Note: If multiple histological findings, include one observation per histological finding.

column7: Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS), with Mixed Embryonal and Alveolar Features

column2: One row per subject per molecular analysis method per molecular abnormality

column5: Age of subject (in days) when molecular analysis was performed.
A molecular or cytogenic abnormality which occurs in either human disease states or disease models.

column10: Note: If multiple molecular abnormalities, include one observation per molecular abnormality.

column5: A variation in or modification of the molecular sequence of a gene or gene product.

column8: Any type of genetic recombination involving exchange of DNA between non-homologous chromosomes, which often occurs as the result of non-homologous end-joining of broken DNA strands. Chromosomal translocation is involved in repairing broken DNA and in maintaining cell viability at the expense of long term genomic stability. This process is is associated with particular types of leukemia, infertility and Down Syndrome.

A structural change in genomic DNA where the 5' to 3' order of a nucleotide sequence is completely reversed to the 3' to 5' order relative to its adjacent sequences. This inversion is termed either pericentric, if it includes the centromere of a chromosome, or pancentric, if it excludes the centromere. An inversion mutation abnormality may be heritable or occur somatically.

Any transmissible change in the genetic material of an organism, which can result from radiation, viral infection, transposition, treatment with mutagenic chemicals and errors during DNA replication or meiosis. The effects of mutation range from single base changes to loss or gain of complete chromosomes. As many of the simpler alterations to DNA may be repaired, such changes are only heritable once the change is fixed in the DNA by the process of replication. Mutations may be associated with genetic diversity or with pathologies including cancer.
A variation of a single nucleotide at a specific location of the genome due to base substitution, which is found at any frequency in the population.
Variation in the number of copies of a particular sequence within the genetic material of an individual. Large-scale copy number polymorphisms are common and widely distributed in the human genome.

Any DNA sequence rearrangement that results in the creation of a novel protein-coding capacity. Within certain genes, gene rearrangement is a normal part of development, facilitating the affinity maturation of B and T lymphocytes as well as class switching of immunoglobulins.

Any rearrangement to the genomic content that results in the loss of one or more nucleotides of DNA. Deletions are generally irreversible rearrangements. They may alter the reading frame of a gene, or may result in loss of large chromosomal regions.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

column5: One of the bodies in the cell nucleus that is the bearer of genes, has the form of a delicate chromatin filament during interphase, contracts to form a compact cylinder segmented into two arms by the centromere during metaphase and anaphase stages of cell division, and is capable of reproducing its physical and chemical structure through successive cell divisions.
The gene symbol that represents either a single gene that has a mutation or the gene that comprises the 5' portion of the coding sequence involved in a fusion gene mutation.
The gene symbol that represents the gene that comprises the 3' portion of the coding sequence for a fusion gene.
An indicator for whether a molecular analysis procedure was performed and whether the assay detected a molecular abnormality.

column8: A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.
A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.
Indicates a task, process or examination that has either not been initiated or not been completed.
Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

column5: Anaplasia
Anaplasia Extent

column5: Age of subject (in days) at procedure.

The worsening of a disease over time.
Either the return of the disease or the progression of the disease.

column5: The number of the disease phase.
The classification of a tumor based primarily on histopathological characteristics.

column8: A tumor at the original site of origin.

A tumor that has spread from its original (primary) site of growth to another site, close to or distant from the primary site. Metastasis is characteristic of advanced malignancies, but in rare instances can be seen in neoplasms lacking malignant morphology.
Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

column5: The anatomical site on which surgery was performed.
A categorization of surgical procedures by type or purpose.

column8: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

column5: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

column8: No detectable presence of residual tumor after treatment
Presence of microscopic residual tumor after treatment.
Presence of macroscopic residual tumor after treatment.
Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

column2: One row per subject per radiation therapy administration

column5: Age of subject (in days) at the start of radiation therapy.
The classification of a tumor based primarily on histopathological characteristics.

column8: A tumor at the original site of origin.

A tumor that has spread from its original (primary) site of growth to another site, close to or distant from the primary site. Metastasis is characteristic of advanced malignancies, but in rare instances can be seen in neoplasms lacking malignant morphology.

column5: Radiation Therapy Site

Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.

column8: A type of external beam radiation therapy using a beam of protons. It has the advantage of precisely localizing the radiation dose on the targeted tissue and avoiding damage to the healthy surrounding tissues.
A single unit of electromagnetic radiation, generally considered to be a discrete particle having no mass or charge.
A type of radiation therapy in which radioactive material is placed inside the body, into a tumor or body cavity.
Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

column5: The total radiation dose administered.
A unit of measurement of the dose of radiation received or absorbed.

column8: A SI derived unit of absorbed radiation dose. One gray is equal to an absorbed dose of one joule per kilogram of matter, or to 100 rads.

column2: One row per subject per response assessment per response method

column5: Age of subject (in days) when the response assessment was made.
Treatment Type Prior to Response Assessment
The pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment. The changes may include eradication of detectable disease, stabilization of disease, or disease progression.
